title: Bwin.Party takeover battle enters final furlong
text:

Sat, Aug 29, 2015, 20:53 BST - UK Markets closed Bwin.Party takeover battle enters final furlong By Ben Martin | Telegraph – 7 minutes ago 5.92 0.00 
GVC and 888 are fighting over online gambling company Bwin and the tussle is set to climax in days 
The £1 bn takeover battle for Bwin.Party has entered the final furlong, with the online gambling company poised this weekend to decide between its two suitors . 
Bwin, the company behind the Foxy Bingo brand, last month recommended a cash and paper offer from 888 that at the time was worth 104.09p a share. 
However, rival GVC, the owner of Sportingtbet, refused to concede defeat and came back with a higher takeover proposal on August 7 that valued Bwin at 125.5p a share. 
Both GVC and Bwin have since been working together to iron out the concerns that the latter had about the former’s bid. 
Bwin last week said those issues had been resolved and then invited the Sportingbet owner to make a formal offer on its “best terms”. GVC is believed to have tabled that offer and an announcement from Bwin updating investors on the state of play is due on Tuesday. 888 will not make decision on whether to increase its bid or walk away until it has seen the terms of the rival approach. 
Bwin has been up for sale since last November with 888 and GVC battling to buy it against a background of sweeping industry consolidation . Betting companies are striking deals with each other in effort to scale-up to offset the impact of higher taxes and stricter regulation. 
Last week, bookmaker Paddy Power (LSE: PAP.L - news ) and betting exchange Betfair revealed they are in merger talks to create one of the world’s biggest online gambling companies generating more than £1.1bn in revenues. In July, Ladbrokes (LSE: LAD.L - news ) and Coral unveiled the terms of a tie-up that will form Britain’s biggest gambling company by betting shops. 
The flurry of deal-making has left William Hill (Other OTC: WIMHF - news ) looking isolated. 
Hill failed in a £720m attempt to buy 888 in February. However, if GVC buys Bwin, 888 would become vulnerable to another approach. 
Alternatively, Hill could attempt to buy rival Betfred or have a tilt at an overseas operator, banking sources said. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is thought that both Paddy Power and Betfair would be too expensive for the bookie. 
Hill, which is in regular contact with its adviser Citigroup (NYSE: C - news ) , is understood to have spoken to its bankers in the wake of the announcement of Paddy Power’s merger with Betfair.
